Award.AwardTitle: Towards the design of Synthetic Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The physicist Richard Feynman is often credited with the remark 'What I cannot create, I do not understand'. The recent history of cell biology is one in which cells have been studied at increasingly simpler and fundamental levels through 'reductionist' experimental approaches. The purpose of this workshop is to utilize that knowledge to address the Feynman dictum and begin the process of building synthetic cells to more fully understand the functions of their natural counterparts. This has the exciting possibility of not only advancing our understanding of biology and regenerative medicine, but also impacting significantly our food security and biomanufacturing industry.

This project will bring together leading scientists from disparate fields of research including cellular and synthetic biology, chemistry, physics, mathematics and bioengineering to plan the construction of synthetic cells. They will address many different questions including 'what is the minimum set of genes, proteins, organelles, small molecules necessary for a cell to function?' and 'what is the minimum set of activities that would define 'function'' among others? By the end of the meeting, the participants should have identified key barriers to success as well as opportunities where concentrated effort could significantly advance the field. They results of the workshop will be a video record of the proceedings, a written report highlighting obstacles and opportunities and the state of the field, and a plan for future collaboration to leverage the work started at the workshop.

The workshop is jointly funded by the Cellular Dynamics and Function Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this grant was to convene a two-day meeting last spring to discuss the state of the art of the field of synthetic or artificial cells.  This meeting brought together biologists, physicists, chemists and engineers working on various aspects of this field.  The meeting was quite productive with all participants indicating that they left with a broader perspective on the progress being made and of the outstanding issues to be focused on in synthetic cell research

 

The idea of building a cell out of nonliving constituents is obviously a very interesting way to learn about the fundamental rules of life. Scientists have been able to build viruses but never anything as complex or as autonomous as a bacterial cell. Roughly speaking one can tackle this problem from the bottom-up or from the top-down. The former involves inserting sets of proteins inside some type of engineered vesicle (either made from lipids as actual cells or from more exotic materials). These sets of proteins can carry out some of the tasks of actual bacteria; for example encapsulated systems may be able to carry out gene transcription or translation and this is the increasing area of research. As the number of different functions is increased, one might approach an object that becomes more and more lifelike. Exactly what constitutes lifelike is of course one of the important conceptual questions that these researchers will have to deal with.

 

The top-down idea starts from an existing bacterial cell and tries to pare it down. Non-essential genes are eliminated one by one while maintaining cellular functionality until no others can be eliminated. The hope is that top-down and bottom-up approaches will eventually converge creating a full landscape of the nonliving to living transition

 

Aside from the obvious rules of life relevance, there are practical applications to this field. The artificial constructs mentioned above can be used for variety of biotech purposes. Even an incomplete understanding of the minimal cell may be able to inform searches for life on extraterrestrial bodies. And, insights into the general problem of non-equilibrium organization may help us build smarter materials even of they are not made of cell-like constituents.
